Federated Learning over Wireless Networks:
A Band-limited Coordinated Descent Approach

Junshan Zhang1, Na Li2, and Mehmet Dedeoglu3 1,3School of Electrical, Computer and Energy Engineering, Arizona State University
2School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University
1Junshan.Zhang@asu.edu, 2nali@seas.harvard.edu, 3Mehmet.Dedeoglu@asu.edu
Abstract

We consider a many-to-one wireless architecture for federated learning at the network edge, where multiple edge devices collaboratively train a model using local data. The unreliable nature of wireless connectivity, together with constraints in computing resources at edge devices, dictates that the local updates at edge devices should be carefully crafted and compressed to match the wireless communication resources available and should work in concert with the receiver. Thus motivated, we propose SGD-based bandlimited coordinate descent algorithms for such settings. Specifically, for the wireless edge employing over-the-air computing, a common subset of k-coordinates of the gradient updates across edge devices are selected by the receiver in each iteration, and then transmitted simultaneously over k sub-carriers, each experiencing time-varying channel conditions. We characterize the impact of communication error and compression, in terms of the resulting gradient bias and mean squared error, on the convergence of the proposed algorithms. We then study learning-driven communication error minimization via joint optimization of power allocation and learning rates. Our findings reveal that optimal power allocation across different sub-carriers should take into account both the gradient values and channel conditions, thus generalizing the widely used water-filling policy. We also develop sub-optimal distributed solutions amenable to implementation.

I Introduction

In many edge networks, mobile and IoT devices collecting a huge amount of data are often connected to each other or a central node wirelessly. The unreliable nature of wireless connectivity, together with constraints in computing resources at edge devices, puts forth a significant challenge for the computation, communication and coordination required to learn an accurate model at the network edge. In this paper, we consider a many-to-one wireless architecture for distributed learning at the network edge, where the edge devices collaboratively train a machine learning model, using local data, in a distributed manner. This departs from conventional approaches which rely heavily on cloud computing to handle high complexity processing tasks, where one significant challenge is to meet the stringent low latency requirement. Further, due to privacy concerns, it is highly desirable to derive local learning model updates without sending data to the cloud. In such distributed learning scenarios, the communication between the edge devices and the server can become a bottleneck, in addition to the other challenges in achieving edge intelligence.

In this paper, we consider a wireless edge network with MùëÄM devices and an edge server, where a high-dimensional machine learning model is trained using distributed learning. In such a setting with unreliable and rate-limited communications, local updates at sender devices should be carefully crafted and compressed to make full use of the wireless communication resources available and should work in concert with the receiver (edge server) so as to learn an accurate model. Notably, lossy wireless communications for edge intelligence presents unique challenges and opportunities [1], subject to bandwidth and power requirements, on top of the employed multiple access techniques. Since it often suffices to compute a function of the sum of the local updates for training the model, over-the-air computing is a favorable alternative to the standard multiple-access communications for edge learning. More specifically, over-the-air computation [2, 3] takes advantage of the superposition property of wireless multiple-access channel via simultaneous analog transmissions of the local messages, and then computes a function of the messages at the receiver, scaling signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) well with an increasing number of users. In a nutshell, when multiple edge devices collaboratively train a model, it is plausible to employ distributed learning over-the-air.

We seek to answer the following key questions: 1) What is the impact of the wireless communication bandwidth/power on the accuracy and convergence of the edge learning? 2) What coordinates in local gradient signals should be communicated by each edge device to the receiver? 3) How should the coordination be carried out so that multiple sender devices can work in concert with the receiver? 4) What is the optimal way for the receiver to process the received noisy gradient signals to be used for the stochastic gradient descent algorithm? 5) How should each sender device carry out power allocation across subcarriers to transmit its local updates? Intuitively, it is sensible to allocate more power to a coordinate with larger gradient value to speed up the convergence. Further, power allocation should also be channel-aware.

To answer the above questions, we consider an integrated learning and communication scheme where multiple edge devices send their local gradient updates over multi-carrier communications to the receiver for learning. Let KùêæK denote the number of subcarriers for communications, where KùêæK is determined by the wireless bandwidth. First, KùêæK dimensions of the gradient updates are determined (by the receiver) to be transmitted. Multiple methods can be used for selecting KùêæK coordinates, e.g., selecting the top-kùëòk (in absolute value) coordinates of the sum of the gradients or randomized uniform selection. This paper will focus on randomly uniform selection (we elaborate further on this in Section V). During the subsequent communications, the gradient updates are transmitted only in the KùêæK-selected dimensions via over-the-air computing over KùêæK corresponding sub-carriers, each experiencing time-varying channel conditions and hence time-varying transmission errors. The devices are subject to power constraints, giving rise to a key question on how to allocate transmission power across dimension, at each edge device, based on the gradient update values and channel conditions. Thus, we explore joint optimization of the power allocation and the learning rate to obtain the best estimate of the gradient updates and minimize the impact of the communication error. We investigate a centralized solution to this problem as a benchmark, and then devise sub-optimal distributed solutions amenable to practical implementation. We note that we have also studied the impact of errors of synchronization across devices in this setting (we omit the details due to limited space).

The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    We take a holistic approach to study federated learning algorithms over wireless MAC channels, and the proposed bandlimited coordinated descent(BLCD) algorithm is built on innovative integration of computing in the air, multi-carrier communications, and wireless resource allocation.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We characterize the impact of communication error and compression, in terms of its resulting gradient bias and mean squared error (MSE), on the convergence performance of the proposed algorithms. Specifically, when the communication error is unbiased, the BLCD algorithm would converge to a stationary point under very mild conditions on the loss function. In the case the bias in the communication error does exist, the iterates of the BLCD algorithm would return to a contraction region centered around a scaled version of the bias infinitely often.

  • ‚Ä¢

    To minimize the impact of the communication error, we study joint optimization of power allocation at individual devices and learning rates at the receiver. Observe that since there exists tradeoffs between bias and variance, minimizing the MSE of the communication error does not necessarily amount to minimizing the bias therein. Our findings reveal that optimal power allocation across different sub-carriers should take into account both the gradient values and channel conditions, thus generalizing the widely used water-filling policy. We also develop sub-optimal distributed solutions amenable to implementation. In particular, due to the power constraints at individual devices, it is not always feasible to achieve unbiased estimators of the gradient signal across the coordinates. To address this complication, we develop a distributed algorithm which can drive the bias in the communication error to (close to) zero under given power constraints and then reduce the corresponding variance as much as possible.

II Related Work

Communication-efficient SGD algorithms are of great interest to reduce latency caused by the transmission of the high dimensional gradient updates with minimal performance loss. Such algorithms in the ML literature are based on compression via quantization [4, 5, 6, 7], sparsification [8, 9, 10] and federated learning [11] (or local updates [12]), where lossless communication is assumed to be provided. At the wireless edge, physical-layer design and communication loss should be taken into consideration for the adoption of the communication-efficient algorithms.

Power allocation for over-the-air computation is investigated for different scenarios in many other works [13, 14, 15, 16, 17] including MIMO, reduced dimensional MIMO, standard many to one channel and different channel models. In related works on ML over wireless channels, [18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25] consider over-the-air transmissions for training of the ML model. The authors in [21] propose sparsification of the updates with compressive sensing for further bandwidth reduction, and recovered sum of the compressed sparse gradients is used for the update. They also apply a similar framework for federated learning and fading channels in [22]. [18] considers a broadband aggregation for federated learning with opportunistic scheduling based on the channel coefficients for a set of devices uniformly distributed over a ring. Lastly, [25] optimize the gradient descent based learning over multiple access fading channels. It is worth noting that the existing approaches for distributed learning in wireless networks do not fully account for the characteristics of lossy wireless channels. It is our hope that the proposed BLCD algorithms can lead to an innovative architecture of distributed edge learning over wireless networks that accounts for computation, power, spectrum constraints and packet losses.

III Federated Learning over Wireless Multi-access Networks

III-A Distributed Edge Learning Model

III-B Bandlimited Coordinate Descent Algorithm

Due to the significant discrepancy between the wireless bandwidth constraint and the high-dimensional nature of the gradient signals, we propose a sparse variant of the SGD algorithm over wireless multiple-access channel, named as bandlimited coordinate descent (BLCD), in which at each iteration only a common set of KùêæK coordinates, I‚Äã(t)‚äÇ{1,‚Ä¶,d}ùêºùë°1‚Ä¶ùëëI(t)\subset\{1,\ldots,d\} (with K‚â™dmuch-less-thanùêæùëëK\ll d), of the gradients are selected to be transmitted through over-the-air computing for the gradient updates. The details of coordinate selection for the BLCD algorithm are relegated to Section VI. Worth noting is that due to the unreliable nature of wireless connectivity, the communication is assumed to be lossy, resulting in erroneous estimation of the updates at the receiver. Moreover, gradient correction is performed by keeping the difference between the update made at the receiver and the gradient value at the transmitter for the subsequent rounds, as gradient correction dramatically improves the convergence rate with sparse gradient updates [9].

For convenience, we first define the gradient sparsification operator as follows.

Definition 1.

III-C BLCD Coordinate Transmissions over Multi-Access Channel

A key step in the BLCD algorithm is to achieve coordinate synchronization of the transmissions among many edge devices. To this end, we introduce a receiver-driven low-complexity multi-access communication protocol, as illustrated in Fig.¬†2, with the function Ct‚Äã(x)subscriptùê∂ùë°ùë•C_{t}(x) denoting the compression of xùë•x at round tùë°t. Let I‚Äã(t)ùêºùë°I(t) (of size KùêæK) denote the subset of coordinates chosen for transmission by the receiver at round tùë°t. Observe that the updates at the receiver are carried out only in the dimensions I‚Äã(t)ùêºùë°I(t). Further, the edge receiver can broadcast its updated iterate to participant devices, over the reverse link. This task is quite simple, given the broadcast nature of wireless channels. In the transmissions, each coordinate of the gradient updates is mapped to a specific subcarrier and then transmitted through the wireless MAC channel, and the coordinates transmitted by different devices over the same subcarrier are received by the edge server in the form of an aggregate sum. It is worth noting that the above protocol is also applicable to the case when the SGD updates are carried out for multiple rounds at the devices.

When there are many edge devices, over-the-air computation can be used to take advantage of superposition property of wireless multiple-access channel via simultaneous analog transmissions of the local updates. More specifically, at round t, the received signal in subcarrier kùëòk is given by:

From the learning perspective, based on {yk}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëòùëò1ùêæ\{y_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}, it is of paramount importance for the receiver to get a good estimate of Gt‚Äã(wt)subscriptùê∫ùë°subscriptùë§ùë°G_{t}(w_{t}). Since nk‚Äã(t)subscriptùëõùëòùë°n_{k}(t) is Gaussian noise, the optimal estimator is in the form of

(G^t‚Äã(wt))k={Œ±l‚Äã(k)‚Äãyl‚Äã(k),k‚ààI‚Äã(t)0otherwisesubscriptsubscript^ùê∫ùë°subscriptùë§ùë°ùëòcasessubscriptùõºùëôùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëôùëòùëòùêºùë°0otherwise\big{(}\widehat{G}_{t}(w_{t})\big{)}_{k}=\begin{cases}\alpha_{l(k)}y_{l(k)},&k\in I(t)\\ 0&\text{otherwise}\end{cases}\vspace{0.05in} (9)

where {Œ±k}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùõºùëòùëò1ùêæ\{\alpha_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K} are gradient estimator coefficients for subcarriers. It follows that the communication error (i.e., the gradient estimation error incurred by lossy communications) is given by

œµt=G^t‚Äã(wt)‚àíGt‚Äã(wt).subscriptitalic-œµùë°subscript^ùê∫ùë°subscriptùë§ùë°subscriptùê∫ùë°subscriptùë§ùë°\epsilon_{t}=\widehat{G}_{t}(w_{t})-G_{t}(w_{t}). (10)

We note that {Œ±k}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùõºùëòùëò1ùêæ\{\alpha_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K} are intimately related to the learning rates for the KùêæK coordinates, scaling the learning rate to be {Œ≥‚ÄãŒ±k}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptùõæsubscriptùõºùëòùëò1ùêæ\{\gamma\alpha_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}. It is interesting to observe that the learning rates in the proposed BLCD algorithm are essentially different across the dimensions, due to the unreliable and dynamically changing channel conditions across different subcarriers.

IV Impact of Communication Error and Compression on BLCD Algorithm

Recall that due to the common sparsification operator across devices, the update in the SGD algorithm at communication round tùë°t is given by

wt+1=wt‚àí[Ct‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãgt‚Äã(wt)+rt)+œµt].subscriptùë§ùë°1subscriptùë§ùë°delimited-[]subscriptùê∂ùë°ùõæsubscriptùëîùë°subscriptùë§ùë°subscriptùëüùë°subscriptitalic-œµùë°w_{t+1}=w_{t}-\big{[}C_{t}(\gamma g_{t}(w_{t})+r_{t})+\epsilon_{t}\big{]}.

Needless to say, the compression operator Ctsubscriptùê∂ùë°C_{t} plays a critical role in sparse transmissions. In this study, we impose the following standard assumption on the compression rate of the operator.

Assumption 1.

For a set of the random compression operators {Ct}t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùê∂ùë°ùë°1ùëá\{C_{t}\}_{t=1}^{T} and any x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, it holds

ùîº‚à•x‚àíCt(x)‚à•2‚â§(1‚àíŒ¥)‚à•x‚à•2\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left\lVert x-C_{t}(x)\right\rVert^{2}\leq(1-\delta)\left\lVert x\right\rVert^{2} (11)

for some Œ¥‚àà(0,1]ùõø01\delta\in(0,1].

We impose the following standard assumptions on the non-convex objective function f‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëì‚ãÖf(\cdot) and the corresponding stochastic gradients gtm‚Äã(wt)subscriptsuperscriptùëîùëöùë°subscriptùë§ùë°g^{m}_{t}(w_{t}) computed with the data samples of device mùëöm in round tùë°t. (We assume that the data samples {Œæm,t}subscriptùúâùëöùë°\{\xi_{m,t}\} are i.i.d.¬†across the devices and time.)

Assumption 2.

(Smoothness) A function f:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñùf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is L-smooth if for all x,y‚àà‚Ñùdùë•ùë¶superscript‚Ñùùëë{x},{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, it holds

Remarks. Based on Theorem¬†1, we have a few observations in order.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We first examine the four terms on the right hand side of (15): The first two terms capture the impact on the gradient by the time average of the bias in the communication error œµtsubscriptitalic-œµùë°\epsilon_{t} and that of the corresponding the mean square, denoted as MSE; the two items would go to zero if the bias and the MSE diminish; the third term is a scaled version of f‚Äã(w0)‚àíf‚àóùëìsubscriptùë§0superscriptùëìf(w_{0})-f^{*} and would go to zero as long as Œ≥=O‚Äã(T‚àíŒ≤)ùõæùëÇsuperscriptùëáùõΩ\gamma=O(T^{-\beta}) with Œ≤<1ùõΩ1\beta<1; and the fourth term is proportional to Œ≥ùõæ\gamma and would go to zero when Œ≥‚Üí0‚Üíùõæ0\gamma\rightarrow 0.

  • ‚Ä¢

    If the right hand side of (15) diminishes as T‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëáT\rightarrow\infty, the iterates in the BLCD algorithm would ‚Äúconverge‚Äù to a neighborhood around Œ∑‚Äã‚à•ùîºt‚Äã[œµt]‚à•2ùúÇsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùîºùë°delimited-[]subscriptitalic-œµùë°2\eta\lVert\mathbb{E}_{t}[\epsilon_{t}]\rVert_{2}, which is a scaled version of the bias in the communication error. For convenience, let œµ¬Ø=lim supt‚à•ùîºt‚Äã[œµt]‚à•2¬Øitalic-œµsubscriptlimit-supremumùë°subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùîºùë°delimited-[]subscriptitalic-œµùë°2\bar{\epsilon}=\limsup_{t}\lVert\mathbb{E}_{t}[\epsilon_{t}]\rVert_{2}, and define a contraction region as follows:

    AŒ≥={wt:‚à•‚àáf‚Äã(wt)‚à•2‚â§(Œ∑+Œî)‚Äãœµ¬Ø}.subscriptùê¥ùõæconditional-setsubscriptùë§ùë°subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àáùëìsubscriptùë§ùë°2ùúÇŒî¬Øitalic-œµA_{\gamma}=\left\{w_{t}:\lVert\nabla f(w_{t})\rVert_{2}\leq(\eta+\Delta)\bar{\epsilon}\right\}.

    where Œî>0Œî0\Delta>0 is an arbitrarily small positive number. It then follows that the iterates in the BLCD algorithm would ‚Äúconverge‚Äù to a contraction region given by AŒ≥subscriptùê¥ùõæA_{\gamma}, in the sense that the iterates return to AŒ≥subscriptùê¥ùõæA_{\gamma} infinitely often. Note that fùëìf is assumed to be any nonconvex smooth function, and there can be many contraction regions, each corresponding to a stationary point.

  • ‚Ä¢

    When the communication error is unbiased, the gradients would diminish to 00 and hence the BLCD algorithm would converge to a stationary point. In the case the bias in the communication error does exist, there exists intrinsic tradeoff between the size of the contraction region and Œ∑‚Äã‚à•ùîºt‚Äã[œµt]‚à•2ùúÇsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùîºùë°delimited-[]subscriptitalic-œµùë°2\eta\lVert\mathbb{E}_{t}[\epsilon_{t}]\rVert_{2}. When the learning rate Œ≥ùõæ\gamma is small, the right hand side of (15) would small, but Œ∑ùúÇ\eta can be large, and vice verse. It makes sense to choose a fixed learning rate that would make Œ∑ùúÇ\eta small. In this way, the gradients in the BLCD algorithm would ‚Äúconcentrate‚Äù around a (small) scaled version of the bias.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Finally, the impact of gradient sparsification is captured by Œ¥ùõø\delta. For instance, when (randomly) uniform selection is used, Œ¥=kdùõøùëòùëë\delta=\frac{k}{d}. We will elaborate on this in Section VI.

V Communication Error Minimization via Joint Optimization of Power Allocation and Learning Rates

Theorem¬†1 reveals that the communication error has a significant impact on the convergence behavior of the BLCD algorithm. In this section, we turn our attention to minimizing the communication error (in term of MSE and bias) via joint optimization of power allocation and learning rates.

Without loss of generality, we focus on iteration tùë°t (with abuse of notation, we omit tùë°t in the notation for simplicity). Recall that the coordinate updates in the BLCD algorithm, sent by different devices over the same subcarrier, are received by the edge server as an aggregate sum, which is used to estimate the gradient value in that specific dimension. We denote the power coefficients and estimators as ùíÉ‚âú[b11,b12,‚Ä¶,b1‚ÄãM,b21,‚Ä¶,bK‚ÄãM]‚âúùíÉsubscriptùëè11subscriptùëè12‚Ä¶subscriptùëè1ùëÄsubscriptùëè21‚Ä¶subscriptùëèùêæùëÄ\bm{b}\triangleq[b_{11},b_{12},\ldots,b_{1M},b_{21},\ldots,b_{KM}] and ùú∂‚âú[Œ±‚Üí1,‚Ä¶,Œ±‚ÜíK]‚âúùú∂subscript‚Üíùõº1‚Ä¶subscript‚Üíùõºùêæ\bm{\alpha}\triangleq[\vec{\alpha}_{1},\ldots,\vec{\alpha}_{K}]. In each round, each sender device optimizes its power allocation for transmitting the selected coordinates of their updates over the KùêæK subcarriers, aiming to achieve the best convergence rate. We assume that the perfect channel state information is available at the corresponding transmitter, i.e., ùíâm=[h1‚Äãm,‚Ä¶,hK‚Äãm]‚ä§subscriptùíâùëösuperscriptsubscript‚Ñé1ùëö‚Ä¶subscript‚Ñéùêæùëötop\bm{h}_{m}=[h_{1m},\ldots,h_{Km}]^{\top} is available at the sender mùëöm only.

Based on (10), the mean squared error of the communication error in iteration tùë°t is given by

ùîºt‚Äã[‚à•œµt‚à•22]=ùîº‚Å°[‚à•G^t‚Äã(wt)‚àíGt‚Äã(wt)‚à•2]subscriptùîºùë°delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptitalic-œµùë°22ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscript^ùê∫ùë°subscriptùë§ùë°subscriptùê∫ùë°subscriptùë§ùë°2\mathbb{E}_{t}[\lVert\epsilon_{t}\rVert_{2}^{2}]=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\bigg{[}\left\lVert\widehat{G}_{t}(w_{t})-G_{t}(w_{t})\right\rVert^{2}\bigg{]} (17)

where the expectation is taken over the channel noise. For convenience, we denote ùîºt‚Äã[‚à•œµt‚à•22]subscriptùîºùë°delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptitalic-œµùë°22\mathbb{E}_{t}[\lVert\epsilon_{t}\rVert_{2}^{2}] as MSE1subscriptMSE1\mbox{{MSE}}_{1}, and after some algebra, it can be rewritten as the sum of the variance and the square of the bias:

MSE1‚Äã(ùú∂,ùíÉ)=‚àëk=1K[‚àëm=1M(Œ±k‚Äãbk‚Äãm‚Äãhk‚Äãm‚àí1M)‚Äãxk‚Äãm‚èübias in¬†kth coordinate]2+‚àëk=1KœÉ2‚ÄãŒ±k2‚èüvariancesubscriptMSE1ùú∂ùíÉsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptdelimited-[]subscript‚èüsuperscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄsubscriptùõºùëòsubscriptùëèùëòùëösubscript‚Ñéùëòùëö1ùëÄsubscriptùë•ùëòùëöbias in¬†kth coordinate2subscript‚èüsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptùúé2subscriptsuperscriptùõº2ùëòvariance\displaystyle\mbox{{MSE}}_{1}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{b})=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\bigg{[}\underbrace{\sum_{m=1}^{M}\left(\alpha_{k}b_{km}h_{km}-\frac{1}{M}\right)x_{km}}_{\mbox{bias in $k$th coordinate}}\bigg{]}^{2}+\underbrace{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sigma^{2}\alpha^{2}_{k}}_{\mbox{variance\ }} (18)

Recall that {Œ±k}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùõºùëòùëò1ùêæ\{\alpha_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K} are intimately related to the learning rates for the KùêæK coordinates, making the learning rate effectively {Œ≥‚ÄãŒ±k}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptùõæsubscriptùõºùëòùëò1ùêæ\{\gamma\alpha_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}.

V-A Centralized Solutions to Minimizing MSE (Scheme 1)

In light of the above, we can cast the MSE minimization problem as a learning-driven joint power allocation and learning rate problem, given by

P1:¬†‚Äãminùú∂,ùíÉP1:¬†subscriptùú∂ùíÉ\displaystyle\textbf{P1:\ }\min_{\bm{\alpha},\bm{b}}\quad MSE1‚Äã(ùú∂,ùíÉ)subscriptMSE1ùú∂ùíÉ\displaystyle\mbox{{MSE}}_{1}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{b}) (19)
s.t. ‚àëk=1K|bk‚Äãm‚Äãxk‚Äãm|2‚â§Em,‚àÄmsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëösubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2subscriptùê∏ùëöfor-allùëö\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\lvert b_{km}x_{km}\right\rvert^{2}\leq E_{m},\quad\forall m (20)
bk‚Äãm‚â•0,Œ±k‚â•0‚àÄk,mformulae-sequencesubscriptùëèùëòùëö0subscriptùõºùëò0for-allùëòùëö\displaystyle b_{km}\geq 0,\ \alpha_{k}\geq 0\quad\forall k,m (21)

which minimizes the MSE for every round.

The above formulated problem is non-convex because the objective function involves the product of variables. Nevertheless, it is biconvex, i.e., for one of the variables being fixed, the problem is convex for the other one. In general, we can solve the above bi-convex optimization problem in the same spirit as in the EM algorithm, by taking the following two steps, each optimizing over a single variable, iteratively:

P1-a:‚Äãminùú∂P1-a:subscriptùú∂\displaystyle\textbf{P1-a:}\ \min_{\bm{\alpha}} MSE1‚Äã(ùú∂,ùíÉ)s.t.Œ±k‚â•0,‚àÄkformulae-sequencesubscriptMSE1ùú∂ùíÉs.t.subscriptùõºùëò0for-allùëò\displaystyle\mbox{{MSE}}_{1}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{b})\quad\textrm{s.t.}\quad\alpha_{k}\geq 0,\quad\forall k
P1-b:‚ÄãminùíÉP1-b:subscriptùíÉ\displaystyle\textbf{P1-b:}\min_{\bm{b}} MSE11‚Äã(ùú∂,ùíÉ)subscriptMSE11ùú∂ùíÉ\displaystyle\mbox{{MSE}}_{11}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{b})
s.t. ‚àëk=1K|bk‚Äãm‚Äãxk‚Äãm|2‚â§Em‚àÄm,bk‚Äãm‚â•0‚àÄk,m.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëösubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2subscriptùê∏ùëöfor-allùëösubscriptùëèùëòùëö0for-allùëòùëö\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\lvert b_{km}x_{km}\right\rvert^{2}\leq E_{m}\ \ \forall m,\quad b_{km}\geq 0\ \ \forall k,m.

Since (P1-a) is unconstrained,for given {bk‚Äãm}subscriptùëèùëòùëö\{b_{km}\}, the optimal solution to (P1-a) is given by

Œ±k‚àó=max‚Å°{(‚àëm=1Mxk‚Äãm)‚Äã(‚àëm=1Mbk‚Äãm‚Äãhk‚Äãm‚Äãxk‚Äãm)M‚Äã[œÉ2+(‚àëm=1Mbk‚Äãm‚Äãhk‚Äãm‚Äãxk‚Äãm)2],0}.subscriptsuperscriptùõºùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄsubscriptùë•ùëòùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄsubscriptùëèùëòùëösubscript‚Ñéùëòùëösubscriptùë•ùëòùëöùëÄdelimited-[]superscriptùúé2superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄsubscriptùëèùëòùëösubscript‚Ñéùëòùëösubscriptùë•ùëòùëö20\displaystyle\alpha^{*}_{k}\!=\!\max\left\{\frac{\big{(}\sum_{m=1}^{M}x_{km}\big{)}\big{(}\sum_{m=1}^{M}b_{km}h_{km}x_{km}\big{)}}{M\big{[}\sigma^{2}+\big{(}\sum_{m=1}^{M}b_{km}h_{km}x_{km}\big{)}^{2}\big{]}},0\right\}. (22)

Then, we can solve (P1-b) by optimizing ùíÉùíÉ\bm{b} only. Solving the sub-problems (P1-a) and (P1-b) iteratively leads to a local minimum, however, not necessarily to the global solution.

Observe that the above solution requires the global knowledge of xk‚Äãmsubscriptùë•ùëòùëöx_{km}‚Äôs and hk‚Äãmsubscript‚Ñéùëòùëöh_{km}‚Äôs of all devices, which is difficult to implement in practice. We will treat it as a benchmark only. Next, we turn our attention to developing distributed sub-optimal solutions.

V-B Distributed Solutions towards Zero Bias and Variance Reduction (Scheme 2)

As noted above, the centralized solution to (P1) requires the global knowledge of xk‚Äãmsubscriptùë•ùëòùëöx_{km}‚Äôs and hk‚Äãmsubscript‚Ñéùëòùëöh_{km}‚Äôs and hence is not amenable to implementation. Further, minimizing the MSE of the communication error does not necessarily amount to minimizing the bias therein since there exists tradeoffs between bias and variance. Thus motivated, we next focus on devising distributed sub-optimal solutions which can drive the bias in the communication error to (close to) zero, and then reduce the corresponding variance as much as possible.

Specifically, observe from (18) that the minimization of MSE cost does not necessarily ensure G^^ùê∫\hat{G} to be an unbiased estimator, due to the intrinsic tradeoff between bias and variance. To this end, we take a sub-optimal approach where the optimization problem is decomposed into two subproblems. In the subproblem at the transmitters, each device mùëöm utilizes its available power and local gradient/channel information to compute a power allocation policy in terms of {b1‚Äãm,b2‚Äãm,‚Ä¶,bK‚Äãm}subscriptùëè1ùëösubscriptùëè2ùëö‚Ä¶subscriptùëèùêæùëö\{b_{1m},b_{2m},\dots,b_{Km}\}. In the subproblem at the receiver, the receiver finds the best possible Œ±ksubscriptùõºùëò\alpha_{k} for all k=1,‚Ä¶,Kùëò1‚Ä¶ùêæk=1,\dots,K. Another complication is that due to the power constraints at individual devices, it is not always feasible to achieve unbiased estimators of the gradient signal across the coordinates. Nevertheless, for given power constraints, one can achieved unbiased estimators of a scaled down version of the coordinates of the gradient signal. In light of this, we formulate the optimization problem at each device (transmitter) mùëöm to ensure an unbiased estimator of a scaled version Œ∂msubscriptùúÅùëö\zeta_{m} of the transmitted coordinates, as follows:

Device¬†m: max{bk‚Äãm}k=1:K‚ÄãŒ∂msubscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëö:ùëò1ùêæsubscriptùúÅùëö\displaystyle\underset{\{b_{km}\}_{k=1:K}}{\max}~{}\zeta_{m} (23)
s.t.‚Äã‚àëk=1Kbk‚Äãm2s.t.superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëö2\displaystyle\text{s.t.}\hskip 7.22743pt\sum_{k=1}^{K}b_{km}^{2} xk‚Äãm2‚â§Em,bk‚Äãm‚â•0,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2subscriptùê∏ùëösubscriptùëèùëòùëö0\displaystyle x_{km}^{2}\leq E_{m},\ \ b_{km}\geq 0, (24)
Œ∂m‚Äãxk‚ÄãmsubscriptùúÅùëösubscriptùë•ùëòùëö\displaystyle\zeta_{m}x_{km} ‚àíbk‚Äãm‚Äãhk‚Äãm‚Äãxk‚Äãm=0,subscriptùëèùëòùëösubscript‚Ñéùëòùëösubscriptùë•ùëòùëö0\displaystyle-b_{km}h_{km}x_{km}=0, ‚àÄk=1,‚Ä¶,K,for-allùëò1‚Ä¶ùêæ\displaystyle\forall k=1,\dots,K, (25)

where maximizing Œ∂msubscriptùúÅùëö\zeta_{m} amounts to maximizing the corresponding SNR (and hence improving the gradient estimation accuracy). The first constraint in the above is the power constraint, and the second constraint is imposed to ensure that there is no bias of the same scaled version of the transmitted signals across the dimensions for user mùëöm. The power allocation solution can be found using Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions as follows:

Œ∂m‚àó=Em‚àëk=1Kxk‚Äãm2hk‚Äãm2,bk‚Äãm‚àó=Œ∂m‚àóhk‚Äãm,‚àÄk.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùúÅùëösubscriptùê∏ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2superscriptsubscript‚Ñéùëòùëö2superscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëösubscriptsuperscriptùúÅùëösubscript‚Ñéùëòùëöfor-allùëò\displaystyle\zeta_{m}^{*}=\sqrt{\frac{E_{m}}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{x_{km}^{2}}{h_{km}^{2}}}},~{}b_{km}^{*}=\frac{\zeta^{*}_{m}}{h_{km}},~{}\forall k. (26)

Observe that using the obtained power allocation policy in (66), all KùêæK transmitted coordinates for device mùëöm have the same scaling factor Œ∂msubscriptùúÅùëö\zeta_{m}. Next, we will ensure zero bias by choosing the right ùú∂ùú∂\bm{\alpha} for gradient estimation at the receiver, which can be obtained by solving the following optimization problem since all transmitted gradient signals are superimposed via the over-the-air transmission:

Receiver side:‚Äãmin{Œ±k},\displaystyle\mbox{\bf Receiver side:}\ \underset{\{\alpha_{k}\},}{\min}~{} ‚àëk=1KŒΩk2‚Äã(Œ±k,{bk‚Äãm‚àó})superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùúàùëò2subscriptùõºùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëö\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\nu}_{k}^{2}(\alpha_{k},\{b_{km}^{*}\}) (27)

Œ±k‚àó=1M‚Äã‚àëm=1Mxk‚Äãm‚àëm=1MŒ∂m‚àó‚Äãxk‚Äãm‚âÉ1‚àëm=1MŒ∂m‚àó,‚àÄk.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùõºùëò1ùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄsubscriptùë•ùëòùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùúÅùëösubscriptùë•ùëòùëösimilar-to-or-equals1superscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùúÅùëöfor-allùëò\displaystyle\alpha_{k}^{*}=\frac{\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^{M}x_{km}}{\sum_{m=1}^{M}\zeta_{m}^{*}x_{km}}\simeq\frac{1}{\sum_{m=1}^{M}\zeta_{m}^{*}},\ \ \forall k. (30)

We note that in the above, from an implementation point of view, since {xk‚Äãm}subscriptùë•ùëòùëö\{x_{km}\} is not available at the receiver, it is sensible to set Œ±k‚Ä†‚âÉ1‚àëm=1MŒ∂m‚àósimilar-to-or-equalssuperscriptsubscriptùõºùëò‚Ä†1superscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùúÅùëö\alpha_{k}^{\dagger}\simeq\frac{1}{\sum_{m=1}^{M}\zeta_{m}^{*}}. Further, {Œ∂m‚àó}superscriptsubscriptùúÅùëö\{\zeta_{m}^{*}\} is not readily available at the receiver either. Nevertheless, since there is only one parameter Œ∂m‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùúÅùëö\zeta_{m}^{*} from each sender mùëöm, the sum ‚àëm=1MŒ∂m‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùúÅùëö\sum_{m=1}^{M}\zeta_{m}^{*} can be sent over a control channel to the receiver to compute Œ±k‚Ä†superscriptsubscriptùõºùëò‚Ä†\alpha_{k}^{\dagger}. It is worth noting that in general the bias exists even if Emsubscriptùê∏ùëöE_{m} is the same for all senders.

Next, we take a closer look at the case when the number of subchannels KùêæK is large (which is often the case in practice). Œ∂m‚àó=Em‚àëk=1Kxk‚Äãm2hk‚Äãm2‚Äã‚üπwhen¬†Kis large‚ÄãŒ∂m‚àó‚âàEmK‚Äã(œÜ2+x¬Ø2)‚Äãœñ2superscriptsubscriptùúÅùëösubscriptùê∏ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2superscriptsubscript‚Ñéùëòùëö2when¬†Kis large‚üπsuperscriptsubscriptùúÅùëösubscriptùê∏ùëöùêæsuperscriptùúë2superscript¬Øùë•2superscriptitalic-œñ2\displaystyle\zeta_{m}^{*}=\frac{\sqrt{E_{m}}}{\sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{x_{km}^{2}}{h_{km}^{2}}}}\underset{\begin{subarray}{c}\text{when $K$}\\ \text{is large}\end{subarray}}{\Longrightarrow}\zeta_{m}^{*}\approx\frac{\sqrt{E_{m}}}{\sqrt{K(\varphi^{2}+\bar{x}^{2})\varpi^{2}}} (31)

As a result, the bias and variance for each dimension kùëòk could be written as,

Observe that when Emsubscriptùê∏ùëöE_{m} is the same across the senders, the bias term ùîºt‚Äã[œµt]=ùüésubscriptùîºùë°delimited-[]subscriptitalic-œµùë°0\mathbb{E}_{t}[\epsilon_{t}]=\mathbf{0} in the above setting according to (32).

V-C A User-centric Approach Using Single-User Solution (Scheme 3)

In this section, we consider a suboptimal user-centric approach, which provides insight on the power allocation across the subcarriers from a single device perspective. We formulate the single device (say user mùëöm) problem as

P2: min{bk‚Äãm},{Œ±k}‚Äã‚àëk=1K[(Œ±k‚Äãbk‚Äãm‚Äãhk‚Äãm‚àí1)‚Äãxk‚Äãm]2+œÉ2‚Äã‚àëk=1KŒ±k2subscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëösubscriptùõºùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùõºùëòsubscriptùëèùëòùëösubscript‚Ñéùëòùëö1subscriptùë•ùëòùëö2superscriptùúé2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptsuperscriptùõº2ùëò\displaystyle\min_{\{b_{km}\},\{\alpha_{k}\}}~{}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\bigg{[}\big{(}\alpha_{k}b_{km}h_{km}-1\big{)}x_{km}\bigg{]}^{2}+\sigma^{2}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha^{2}_{k}

Based on the above result, in the multi-user setting, each device can adopt the above single-user power allocation solution as given in Theorem 2. This solution can be applied individually without requiring any coordination between devices.

We can compute the bias and the variance accordingly.

VI Coordinate Selection for Bandlimited Coordinate Descent Algorithms

The selection of which coordinates to operate on is crucial to the performance of sparsified SGD algorithms. It is not hard to see that selecting the top-kùëòk (in absolute value) coordinates of the sum of the gradients provides the best performance. However, in practice it may not always be feasible to obtain top-kùëòk of the sum of the gradients, and in fact there are different solutions for selecting kùëòk dimensions with large absolute values; see e.g., [22, 27]. Note that each device individually transmitting top-kùëòk coordinates of their local gradients is not applicable to the scenario of over-the-air communications considered here. Sequential device-to-device transmissions provides an alternative approach [28], but these techniques are likely to require more bandwidth with wireless connection.

Another approach that is considered is the use of compression and/or sketching for the gradients to be transmitted. For instance, in [22], a system that updates SGD via decompressing the compressed gradients transmitted through over-the-air communication is examined. To the best of our knowledge, such techniques do not come with rigorous convergence guarantees. A similar approach is taken in [27], where the sketched gradients are transmitted through an error-free medium and these are then used to obtain top-kùëòk coordinates; the devices next simply transmit the selected coordinates. Although such an approach can be taken with over-the-air computing since only the summation of the sketched gradients is necessary; this requires the transmission of ùí™‚Äã(k‚Äãlog‚Å°d)ùí™ùëòùëë\mathcal{O}(k\log d) dimensions. To provide guarantees with such an approach ùí™‚Äã(k‚Äãlog‚Å°d+k)ùí™ùëòùëëùëò\mathcal{O}(k\log d+k) up-link transmissions are needed. Alternatively, uniformly selected ùí™‚Äã(k‚Äãlog‚Å°d+k)ùí™ùëòùëëùëò\mathcal{O}(k\log d+k) coordinates can be transmitted with similar bandwidth and energy requirements. For the practical learning models with non-sparse updates, uniform coordinate selection tend to perform better. Moreover, the common KùêæK dimensions can be selected uniformly via synchronized pseudo-random number generators without any information transfer. To summarize, uniform selection of the coordinates is more attractive based on the energy, bandwidth and implementation considerations compared to the methods aiming to recover top-kùëòk coordinates; indeed, this is the approach we adopt.

VII Experimental Results

In this section, we evaluate the accuracy and convergence performance of the BLCD algorithm, when using one of the following three schemes for power allocation and learning rate selection (aiming to minimize the impact of communication error): 1) the bi-convex program based solution (Scheme 1), 2) the distributed solution towards zero bias in Section¬†V. (Scheme 2); 3) the single-user solution (Scheme 3). We use the communication error free scheme as the baseline to evaluate the performance degradation. We also consider the naive scheme (Scheme 4) using equal power allocation for all dimensions, i.e., bk‚Äãm=E/‚àëk=1Kxk‚Äãm2subscriptùëèùëòùëöùê∏superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptsuperscriptùë•2ùëòùëöb_{km}=\sqrt{E/{\sum_{k=1}^{K}x^{2}_{km}}}.

In our first experiment, we consider a simple single layer neural network trained on the MNIST dataset. The network consists of two 2-D convolutional layers with filter size 5√ó5555\times 5 followed by a single fully connected layer and it has 7840 parameters. K=64ùêæ64K=64 dimensions are uniformly selected as the support of the sparse gradient transmissions. For convenience, we define Ea‚Äãv‚Äãgsubscriptùê∏ùëéùë£ùëîE_{avg} as the average sum of the energy (of all devices) per dimension normalized by the channel noise variance, i.e., Ea‚Äãv‚Äãg=E‚ÄãM‚Äãùîº‚Å°[hk‚Äãm2]/K‚ÄãœÉ2.subscriptùê∏ùëéùë£ùëîùê∏ùëÄùîºsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñéùëòùëö2ùêæsuperscriptùúé2E_{avg}=EM\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[h_{km}^{2}]/K\sigma^{2}. Without loss of generality, we take the variance of the channel noise as œÉ2=1superscriptùúé21\sigma^{2}=1 and {hk‚Äãm}subscript‚Ñéùëòùëö\{h_{km}\} are independent and identically distributed Rayleigh random variables with mean 111. The changes on Ea‚Äãv‚Äãgsubscriptùê∏ùëéùë£ùëîE_{avg} simply amount to different SNR values. In Fig. 4, we take K=64ùêæ64K=64, M=8ùëÄ8M=8, batch size 444 to calculate each gradient, and the learning rate Œ≥=0.01ùõæ0.01\gamma=0.01. In the second experiment, we expand the model to a more sophisticated 555-layer neural network and an 181818-layer ResNet [29] with 617066170661706 and 111753701117537011175370 parameters, respectively. The 555-layer network consists of two 2-D convolutional layers with filter size 5√ó5555\times 5 followed by three fully connected layers. In all experiments, we have used a learning rate of 0.010.010.01. the local dataset of each worker is randomly selected from the entire MNIST dataset. We use 101010 workers with varying batch sizes and we utilize K=1024ùêæ1024K=1024 sub-channels for sparse gradient signal transmission.

It can be seen from Fig.¬†4 that in the presence of the communication error, the centralized solution (Scheme 1) based on bi-convex programming converges quickly and performs the best, and it can achieve accuracy close to the ideal error-free scenario. Further, the distributed solution (Scheme 2) can eventually approach the performance of Scheme 1, but the single-user solution (Scheme 3) performs poorly, so does the naive scheme using equal power allocation (Scheme 4). Clearly, there exists significant gap between its resulting accuracy and that in the error-free case, and this is because the bias in Scheme 3 is more significantly.

Next, Figures¬†4, 6 and 6 depict the results in the second experiment using much larger-scale deep neural networks. It can be observed from Figs.¬†4, 6 and 6 that the SNR can have significant impact on the final accuracy. As expected, the convergence on the ResNet network is slower in comparison to other DNNs due to the huge number of parameters and small batch size. Nevertheless, it is clear that the learning accuracy improves significantly at high SNR. (The solution of the distributed algorithm for Ea‚Äãv‚Äãg=10subscriptùê∏ùëéùë£ùëî10E_{avg}=10 is omitted in Fig. 6, since it is indistinguishably close to error-free solution.) It is interesting to observe that when the SNR increases, the distributed solution (Scheme 2) can achieve accuracy close to the ideal error-free case, but the single-user solution (Scheme 3) would not. It is worth noting that due to the computational complexity of bi-convex programming in this large-scale case, Scheme 4 could be solved effectively (we did not present it here). Further, the batch size at each worker can impact the convergence rate, but does not impact the final accuracy.

VIII Conclusions

In this paper, we consider a many-to-one wireless architecture for distributed learning at the network edge, where multiple edge devices collaboratively train a machine learning model, using local data, through a wireless channel. Observing the unreliable nature of wireless connectivity, we design an integrated communication and learning scheme, where the local updates at edge devices are carefully crafted and compressed to match the wireless communication resources available. Specifically, we propose SGD-based bandlimited coordinate descent algorithms employing over-the-air computing, in which a subset of k-coordinates of the gradient updates across edge devices are selected by the receiver in each iteration and then transmitted simultaneously over k sub-carriers. We analyze the convergence of the algorithms proposed, and characterize the effect of the communication error. Further, we study joint optimization of power allocation and learning rates therein to maximize the convergence rate. Our findings reveal that optimal power allocation across different sub-carriers should take into account both the gradient values and channel conditions. We then develop sub-optimal solutions amenable to implementation and verify our findings through numerical experiments.

(66) illustrates that the mùëömth transmitter utilizes all of its power budget to amplify its transmitted local gradient signal. However, the received signal at the receiver is a superposition of all transmitted signals because of the over-the-air transmission. A-E Alternative Formulations and Baselines

A Receiver Centric Approach. In what follows, we take a receiver-centric approach by selecting a fixed estimator, Œ±k=1M‚Äãp,‚àÄksubscriptùõºùëò1ùëÄùëùfor-allùëò\alpha_{k}=\frac{1}{Mp},\forall k, at the receiver. Given the fixed estimator, the MSE objective function is set as

MSE‚Äã(1/(M‚Äãp),ùíÉ)=‚àëk=1K‚àëm=1M(bk‚Äãm‚Äãhk‚ÄãmM‚Äãp‚àí1M)2‚Äãxk‚Äãm2+‚àëk=1K‚àëm=1M‚àëm‚Ä≤=1m‚Ä≤‚â†mM(bk‚Äãm‚Äãhk‚ÄãmM‚Äãp‚àí1M)√ó(bk‚Äãm‚Ä≤‚Äãhk‚Äãm‚Ä≤M‚Äãp‚àí1M)‚Äãxk‚Äãm‚Äãxk‚Äãm‚Ä≤+œÉ2‚ÄãKM2‚Äãp2.MSE1ùëÄùëùùíÉsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëösubscript‚ÑéùëòùëöùëÄùëù1ùëÄ2superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëö‚Ä≤1superscriptùëö‚Ä≤ùëöùëÄsubscriptùëèùëòùëösubscript‚ÑéùëòùëöùëÄùëù1ùëÄsubscriptùëèùëòsuperscriptùëö‚Ä≤subscript‚Ñéùëòsuperscriptùëö‚Ä≤ùëÄùëù1ùëÄsubscriptùë•ùëòùëösubscriptùë•ùëòsuperscriptùëö‚Ä≤superscriptùúé2ùêæsuperscriptùëÄ2superscriptùëù2\begin{split}\mbox{{MSE}}(1/(Mp),\bm{b})&=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\big{(}\frac{b_{km}h_{km}}{Mp}-\frac{1}{M}\big{)}^{2}x_{km}^{2}\\ &+\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}m^{\prime}=1\\ m^{\prime}\neq m\end{subarray}}^{M}\big{(}\frac{b_{km}h_{km}}{Mp}-\frac{1}{M}\big{)}\times\big{(}\frac{b_{km^{\prime}}h_{km^{\prime}}}{Mp}-\frac{1}{M}\big{)}x_{km}x_{km^{\prime}}+\sigma^{2}\frac{K}{M^{2}p^{2}}.\end{split}

We note that the first term can be decomposed for different devices and be solved in a distributed manner. The second term is coupled across different users, and the third term is only expressed in terms of the variable pùëùp. If there were no power constraints, the solution would be bk‚Äãm‚Äãhk‚Äãm=psubscriptùëèùëòùëösubscript‚Ñéùëòùëöùëùb_{km}h_{km}=p for a very large pùëùp. With this intuition, it is sensible to assign most (if not all) of the multipliers (bk‚Äãm‚Äãhk‚ÄãmM‚Äãp‚àí1M)subscriptùëèùëòùëösubscript‚ÑéùëòùëöùëÄùëù1ùëÄ(\frac{b_{km}h_{km}}{Mp}-\frac{1}{M}) zero. That is to say, pùëùp should be selected so that it fits most users to provide enough power for the transmission of all the dimensions, while every user individually solves the power allocation problem using the first term for a given value of pùëùp, i.e.,

P2-1:¬†‚Äãmin{bk‚Äãm}P2-1:¬†subscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëö\displaystyle\textbf{P2-1:\ }\min_{\{b_{km}\}} ‚àëk=1K(bk‚Äãm‚Äãhk‚ÄãmM‚Äãp‚àí1M)2‚Äãxk‚Äãm2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëösubscript‚ÑéùëòùëöùëÄùëù1ùëÄ2superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\big{(}\frac{b_{km}h_{km}}{Mp}-\frac{1}{M}\big{)}^{2}x_{km}^{2}
s.t. ‚àëk=1Kbk‚Äãm2‚Äãxk‚Äãm2‚â§E.superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëö2superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2ùê∏\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}b_{km}^{2}x_{km}^{2}\leq E.

The optimal solution {bk‚Äãm‚àó}superscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëö\{b_{km}^{*}\} to the problem (P2-1) can be obtained by finding Œª‚àó‚â•0superscriptùúÜ0\lambda^{*}\geq 0 satisfying the following two inequalities:

‚àëk=1K(bk‚Äãm‚àó)2‚Äãxk‚Äãm2‚â§E,bk‚Äãm‚àó=xk‚Äãm2‚Äãphk‚Äãm‚Äã(xk‚Äãm2‚àíM2‚Äãp2‚ÄãŒªm‚àó).formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëö2superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2ùê∏subscriptsuperscriptùëèùëòùëösuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2ùëùsubscript‚Ñéùëòùëösuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2superscriptùëÄ2superscriptùëù2subscriptsuperscriptùúÜùëö\sum_{k=1}^{K}(b_{km}^{*})^{2}x_{km}^{2}\leq E,\quad b^{*}_{km}=\frac{x_{km}^{2}p}{h_{km}(x_{km}^{2}-M^{2}p^{2}\lambda^{*}_{m})}. (76)

When Œª‚àó=0superscriptùúÜ0\lambda^{*}=0, then the solution is bk‚Äãm‚àó=p/hk‚Äãmsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëöùëùsubscript‚Ñéùëòùëöb_{km}^{*}=p/h_{km}, the objective function is minimized to 0 and the power constraint is satisfied with strict inequality. On contrary, when Œª‚àó>0superscriptùúÜ0\lambda^{*}>0, then the power constraint is satisfied with equality and the optimal solution bk‚Äãm‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëöb_{km}^{*} deviates from p/hk‚Äãmùëùsubscript‚Ñéùëòùëöp/h_{km}. ‚àëk=1K(bk‚Äãm‚àó)2‚Äãxk‚Äãm2=E,bk‚Äãm‚àó=xk‚Äãm2‚Äãphk‚Äãm‚Äã(xk‚Äãm2‚àíM2‚Äãp2‚ÄãŒªm‚àó).formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëö2superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2ùê∏subscriptsuperscriptùëèùëòùëösuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2ùëùsubscript‚Ñéùëòùëösuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2superscriptùëÄ2superscriptùëù2subscriptsuperscriptùúÜùëö\sum_{k=1}^{K}(b_{km}^{*})^{2}x_{km}^{2}=E,\quad b^{*}_{km}=\frac{x_{km}^{2}p}{h_{km}(x_{km}^{2}-M^{2}p^{2}\lambda^{*}_{m})}. (77)

An equal power allocation approach. For comparison, we also consider the equal power allocation scheme, in which equal power is allocated to each dimension, i.e., we set bk‚Äãm=bmsubscriptùëèùëòùëösubscriptùëèùëöb_{km}=b_{m}. Enforcing the power constraint of the devices, e.g., ‚àëk=1Kbk‚Äãm2‚Äãxk‚Äãm2=Esuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëòùëö2superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëòùëö2ùê∏\sum_{k=1}^{K}b_{km}^{2}x_{km}^{2}=E, leads to the equal power solution that can be written as bm‚àó=E/‚àëk=1Kxk‚Äãm2superscriptsubscriptùëèùëöùê∏superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptsuperscriptùë•2ùëòùëöb_{m}^{*}=\sqrt{E/{\sum_{k=1}^{K}x^{2}_{km}}}. Therefore, each device applies the power bm‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëöb_{m}^{*} in each dimension, taking the advantage of the distribution of the data which is independent and identical.

An Alternative Formulation to P3.

When KùêæK is large, the channel coefficients {hk‚Äãm}subscript‚Ñéùëòùëö\{h_{km}\} and the local gradients {xk‚Äãm}subscriptùë•ùëòùëö\{x_{km}\} are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) across all users and subchannels. Hence, the optimization problem P3 can be further simplified via the law of large numbers as
